Dinner-Dance
A dinner-dance will be held in
commemoration of its 30th reunion by the class of 1926, also
tonight in Levering cafeteria at
7 p.m.
Tomorrow's observance will begin at 9 a.m. with a breakfast
meeting of the branch Alumni
Association presidents, also in
Levering Hall. At 11 a.m. attending alumni will be taken on tours
of the campus. The tours, to be
led by students, will originate at
Levering Hall.
Movie On JHU
Also at 11 a.m. tomorrow morning, alumni will be shown the new
color sound film,"The Johns Hopkins University." The film will be
shown in Shriver Hall auditorium.
It will be shown for the second
time at 11:30 a.m. in Shriver.
There will be a buffet luncheon
in the Homewood gymnasium at
12 noon tomorrow. Tickets for the
luncheon are $2.50 per person.
The classes of 1892, 1893, 1896,
1945, and 1946 will hold reunion
luncheons at 12:30 p.m. in the
Hopkins Club; and the Wives
Committee of the Class of 1932
will hold its luncheon at the same
time, also in the Hopkins Club.
Parade Of Classes
Led by Dr. Lowell J. Reed, president of the University, and Mr.
M. Jenkins Cromwell, class of '32

Sanford Cohen, retiring Chairman of the Honor Commission,
after reviewing the commission's
activities, has called it a year of
progress.
Cohen explained his estimation
of how well the Commission has
fulfilled its purpose. "The Honor
Commission has a dual purpose;
to uphold and promote the traditions of the Johns Hopkins University Honor System. This dual
purpose is stated in Article I of
the commission's constitution and
this year we have tried to accomplish both of the tasks with which
we were charged."
Upholding the Honor system at
Hopkins means to most people
the holding of trials for alleged
academic violations, Cohen pointed
out, adding that there is much
more involved.

Only be attributed to the fact that
more people are aware of their
responsibility to turn in any possible violation than in previous
years. "This increased awareness
of the responsibility on the part of
Individuals, I believe, has come
as a result of the program which
was followed in promoting the
Honor System this year," stated
Cohen.
Ideals Stressed
The ideals behind an Honor
System were stressed during Orientation, Cohen pointed out, and
because of the favorable response,
was stressed
the same line
throughout the year. "Each member of this year's commission deserves credit for the job that he
has done in promoting the ideals
underlying the moral code of
ethics which the commission must
uphold and promote," said the
commission chairman.
"Promotion of the system was
achieved through increased faculty-student understanding and
cooperation brought about through
the efforts of President Reed,
Dean Shaffer, Dean Roy, Dr.

SANFORD COHEN
Boas, and other faculty and administrative leaders. Problems in
administering the system were
brought to the attention of the
faculty and corrective action was
taken by both the faculty and
the commission members," Cohen
said.

Gavels Given To Wheels
Presentation of gavels to Sandy
Cohen, the retiring head of the
Honor Commission, to Bob Peinado of the Student Council, and
Herb Belgrad of the SAC., will
take place in pre-game ceremonies at the Maryland-Hopkins
Homecoming lacrosse game tomorrow.
Immediately following these
presentations the awards will be
made to the freshman who has
been most active in student activities, and to the freshman who
has contributed most to athletics
during the year.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 18, 1956

NEWS -LETTER

Tap of new members will take
place. Trustee Albert Hutzler, Sr.,
Herb Belgrad and Student Council Member Jim Pessin will do
the tapping. The selections to
ODK are made on the basis of
qualifications set down by the
National Society: character, leadership, and service in campus life,
scholarship, fellowship, and the
consecration to democratic ideals.
Membership is awarded to juniors
and seniors irrespective of membership in or affiliation with other
organizations and is "considered
a mark of high achievement and
honor," according to Belgrad.

SC Reveals
Voting Delay
Of No Set Time
The Student Council referendum on its proposed constitution,
scheduled for last Wednesday and
Thursday, will be postponed indefinitely until some time in October as a result of action taken
at last Monday's SC meeting.
Penn Lupovitch, Constitution
Committee chairman, stated, "I
wish to apologize for the poor job
that has been done on this proposed referendum. If any blame
is to be laid, it must be here."
Added Lupovitch, "The Council
tried very hard to do this thing
correctly. The next time it will be
done correctly."
Lew Sank, president of the SC,
felt that "it would be more advantageous to the students to let
them express themselves by voting on the constitution" in explaining why he stepped down
from the chair to argue against
postponement. Said Sank, "The
SC made adequate attempts to
receive all discussions and suggestions. I felt that rather than
wait a year, the SC could obtain
overall opinion on the constitution by this referendum. The
majority of the SC felt that they
would rather be sure of student
support. To my mind the SC was
afraid of the present apathy which
exists in the dorm concerning
governing bodies and constitutions in general."
Lupovitch explained that the
action was taken after the meeting ran an hour and a half because the SC "general concensus
of opinion [was] that the student body had not been adequately
informed as to the intent and objects of the S.C. constitution. We,
as representatives of the student
body, feel that there has not been
enough time devoted to explanation and clarification on this proposed constitution," said Lupovitch.

will begin Saturday afternoon's

At 2 p.m. the student-sponsored float parade will march
onto the field, and the annual
Hopkins-Maryland lacrosse game

ODK Tap
Half-time ceremonies, scheduled
to begin at 3:30 p.m. will commence with the annual spring
ODK tap. Also at half-time, the
winners of the float contest will be
announced, and the Homecoming Queen will be crowned.
Following the completion of the
lacrosse game, at 5 p.m., the fraternities will hold open-house for
all visiting alumni, and the class
of 1929 will hold a get-together
in Shriver Hall. ODK initiates will
be formally inducted into the

Garman said that an experience

Dinners And Dinners
The class of 1921 will hold its
reunion dinner at 5:30 p.m. in the
Hopkins Club; and at 6 p.m. the
classes of 1901, 1907, 1911 will
also hold reunion dinners at the
Club. The class of 1936 will dine
in Levering Hall, and the class
of 1941 at the University Club.
The class of 1951 will hold its fifth
reunion dinner at the Merchants'
Club.
At 7 p.m. the classes of 1906,
1916, and 1931 will hold their
dinners at the Hopkins Club.
Sponsored by the H-Club, the
annual Starlighter Dance, on the
Gilman Hall Terrace, will close
out Saturday's festivities at 9
p.m.
Homecoming celebrations will
wind up on Sunday with a brunch
for the class of 1931 at the home
of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Pfeffer
at 12 noon, the Orchestra concert
in Shriver Hall at 3 p.m., and a
4:30 Jazz Concert in the Keyser
Quadrangle.

Newman Club Plans
Senior Celebration
The third annual Newman Club
Baccalaureate Breakfast and Mass
and Communion will be celebrated
to "fete the Club's graduating seniors" Sunday, May 27, according to Club president Bob Boucek.
Mas.s will be said by Fr. Manuel Roman, the first president of
the Newman Club's Hopkins grouP
who will celebrate his first mass.
He will be ordained the day before the celebration at 10:45 ill
St. Philip and James Church.
A steak breakfast at the House
of Welch will follow the Church
ceremony. Fr. Edward Gleason,
Rector of St. Peter's Seminary in
Catonsville, will be the main
speaker. Tickets can be obtained
at a price of $2.00 from the officers of the Club, Boucek said.

By LARRY WOLF

Booster Club, will be held at 8
p.m. this evening in the court in
front of the Dormitories.
The rally, which, according to
chairman Bob Mitgang, is intended to "continue the tremendous spirit shown by Hopkins rooters at the Navy game," will feature free beer and pretzels, a three
to five piece jazz combo playing
on an open truck, the University
Band, representatives of the teams

'Baloo Resets Date
For Taking Orders
The Hullabaloo has reset the
deadline for placing orders from
May 15 to June 1. According to
Paul Abrams, editor-in-chief, the
change was decided upon to allow
those who have waited to the last
moment, to place their orders.
Bill Bain, next year's editor-inchief reported that the '56 "is
doing all right and is not behind,
contrary to popular opinion. The
book is on schedule both with ourselves and with the printer."
Two more selections for the staff
of the '57 Hullabaloo have been
made by Bain: Nick Karas, photographer and Al Schlecter, Senior section editor. "No further
plans have been made. We're still
waiting for estimates on the printing process. I can report that we
are still going to try to use color
pages and use them more, if possible."

Spirit Aids Squad
Mitgang stated, "This being
Homecoming Weekend, naturally
the emphasis is on the Maryland
lacrosse game. Spirit helped the
team sink Navy last week, and I
hope it can help the team end
Maryland's winning streak. If the
rally gets going, I expect it will
move off the campus and form a
moving rally."
Tomorrow afternoon, the Booster Club will also sponsor a Homecoming Float Parade before the
Hopkins-Maryland lacrosse tilt.
Many Entries
Lou Kady, chairman of the
Booster Club Homecoming Committee, reports that "more groups
are entering the contest than ever
before."
Entries have been received from
fourteen fraternities: AD, AE Pi,
ATO, APO, Beta, Beta Tau, DU,
Delta Phi, KA, Phi Gam, Phi Ep,
Phi Psi, Phi Sig, and Sig Ep. Last
year's winning float was that of
AD.
50 Years Ago
The theme of the contest this
year is "Hopkins, 50 Years Ago."
The winning float, which will be
announced'at half-time, will gain
for its organization the Booster
Club's trophy for one year, and
permanent possession of a smaller
trophy. In addition, its queen will
be proclaimed, "Queen of Homecoming." The Queen will also be
presented at the H-Club's Starlighter Dance tomorrow evening.

Needed: The Human Touch

At the present time, the Alumni Memorial Residences
are not the most pleasant place in which to live. There is
very little, if any, feeling of belonging to a community
amongst those who reside in them.
This morning the Hopkins' film "The University" stated
through the words of John Masefield, one of the prime functions of a university. This is to "give the young people that
close companionship for which youth longs ... and that
chance of the endless discussion of the themes which are
endless ... without which youth would seem a waste of
time." Although this vital spirit of companionship is not
totally wanting in the dorms, it is effectively suppressed.
The residency is divided in an amazingly thorough manner. Fraternity men tend to be at least socially separated
from independents. Engineers are curricularly separated
from men in the school of Arts and Sciences. To a lesser
degree, the classes are separated, merely through associations. The house system, whereby the dormitories are divided
into separate entries was originally planned to promote
a strong unity of subdivisions. However, in its present
status, the system encourages the isolation of cliques rather
than the desired unity of medium sized groups.
By themselves, none of these separations are final
enough to cause the sense of disunity to be present. The
isolation factor is this: although there are several points
at which the interest and activities of the residents of the
dormitory differ, there is no encouragement for a union of
the various factors, nor is there any obvious advantage in
such a union. There is no common ground for an amalgamation.
The dormitory resident needs to feel that he belongs
to more than his immediate circle of friends if the previously stated goal of the university is to be fulfilled. He
needs a place, and above all, a reason to break his cliques.
At the present time there is no situation or location conducive to informal discussions between non-acquainted dormitory residents. The provision of a room for such purposes
would not be sufficient; indeed, there are ample facilities
available at present.
Perhaps a suggestion could be taken from "The University," which depicted a. member of the faculty mingling
with dormitory student in what is loosely termed a bull
session. If student-faculty discussions such as this actually
did take place in the dormitories, a step would be taken in
the provision of an opyortunity to discuss "the themes
which are endless." An arrangement in the order of the
'Y' Coffee Hours in the dormitories might suffice for a
beginning.
Another serious oversight in planning a well-rounded
dormitory life is the lack of an effective social program.
There is no provision for an informal mixing of the sees.
With the exception of the few, and only partially effective,
mixers, all acquaintances are made off campus. It would
not be impossible for the less aggressive 'resident of the
Alumni Memorial Residences to go throughout the academic
year without more than a passing acquaintance with the
opposite sex.
Since it is impossible for the four year student to have
a complete understanding of a situation which has built .up
over a period of years, without direct knowledge of what
the past held, or of what possibilities of improvement may
exist, we feel that it is not the part of the student to attempt to ameliorate the present oppressive atmosphere in
the dormitories. We must place our hope in an administrative understanding of the situation to guide the needed
changes.

Collegiate Tradition Expressed
In Riots, Raids, Boisterousness

s

NO RIOT HERE
Collegiate tradition points to
riots, raids, and boisterousness as
one of the signs that spring has
come to the collegiate community.
A quick scanning of the newspapers any weekend quickly bears
this out.
At Hopkins, tradition seems to
be hurting, for busy students, sunbathers, and "stickmen" aren't
very indicative of riotus universitatus. A number of reasons could
be advanced for this unusual behavior, not the least of which
would be that there has been unfavorable weather—either too hot,
too cold, or too rainy. Any student of collegiat spring riots is
fully aware that the hearty men
are not so dedicated to their principles of boisterousness to venture forth without proper weather.
So far this year, Dean Shaffer has
been blessed with adverse weather.
But. the University of Pennsylvania administration has not been
nearly so lucky.
It seems that a couple of weeks
ago, spring in all her glory came
to Philadelphia. It was one of
those days of which riot leaJcrs
dream, warm and balmy without
any activity. It was a Thursday.
This fracas, as do so many, started
quite innocently. Four men destined to achieve the goal of riot
leader, \--ere playing softball in
the street adjacent to the campus.
Playing ball with four People for
a couple of hours after supper
finally loses it,s enjoyment and this
game was no exception.
Nearby an ancient building was
rapidly coming to its inglorious
end at the hands of a wrecking
Company. To one of these budding
geniuses tiring of softball the idea
of placing debris from the building in the middle of the street
presented itself. This plan was
eagerly adopted by the other members of the quartet and they were
soon joined in the task by numerous undergraduate friends. This
was 9 P.M.
At 2 A.M., squads of weary
Policemen could finally return to
their stations. At 2 A.M., 116
Penn undergraduates were experiencing booking on the police
blotter. In the intervening five
hours buses, streetcars, autos, and
trucks had been blocked, eggs and
then stones had been hurled at
the policemen, some so accurately
that two officers had been injured, one requiring hospitaliza-

tion. On Friday in the solemn confines of Philadelphia Police Court
bengath the stern countenance of
magistrate John L. Carlyle, 28
were given a hearing and ordered
held on $500 bail on disorderly
conduct charges.
Apparently all is not over, for
Dr. Gayland P. Harnwell, president of the University of Pennsylvania, is quite disturbed over the
incident and has promised strong
disciplinary action.

them, Brown University's students

NEWS-LETTER

PAGE SEVEN

Stickmen Continue Win Streak;
To Battle Maryland Tomorrow
By AL FIGINSKI
Assistant Sports Editor

By BOB MARTINI
Sports Editor

The Jay lacrosse squad, having won six games in a
row, face their toughest match of the season tomorrow
when they take on the highly touted Terrapins of Maryland
in the annual Homecoming game. Maryland, as expected,
has dominated the collegiate lacrosse scene this year, winning
10 straight contests and adding to their consecutive game
streak which has now reached 22 in a row. The streak,
ironically enough, began on Homecoming Day in 1954
When the Terps massacred Hopkins by a 17-4 score. From
this corner, this would be just as good a time as any to break
the Maryland bubble. Whether the Jaks have the club that
can do it or not remains the burning question. Hopkins this
year has had its best season since the 1950 championship
team. After dropping their first two tilts by one-goal margins, the Jays found themselves and, despite a severe lack
of fan support in their next four games, whipped all four
Opponents, including highly rated Army. After beating Army
the Jays returned home to face R.P.I. in a game which saw
one of the biggest crowds of the season turn out. The fans
were treated to a marvelous game, the Jays coming back
from a four goal deficit to whip Rensselaer, 10-7. Last week
Hopkins capped their six-game streak by upsetting Navy
by an 8-6 count.

Maryland, who will carry a 22
game winning streak into tomorrow's fray, are led by their two
co-captains, Gruder Miller, attackman, and Jack Simmons, defenseman. The visitors will also
bring with them their two leading
scorers, Jim Keating and Charlie
Wicker, who will pose a definite
threat to the Hopkins defense.
Terps Hold Edge
Statistically the Terps hold the
edge. In ten games the champs
have averaged 15.1 goals per game
offensively, while holding their op-

ponents to a mean of 4.6 goals.
The Jays possess an 8.5 average
offensively and hold a 5 goal average defensively.
Both teams have several reasons
for wanting to capture a victory
tomorrow. Hopkins hopes to extend their winning streak to seven
games; gain second place in the
final Cy Miller division and national rankings; end the long
Terp winning streak that was
started two years ago at the Jays'
expense and win their first Homecoming since 1951.

Arlyn Marshall, Jay Co-captain, brings the ball upfield in an
intra-squad game as the Jays prepare for tomorrow's clash with
Maryland. Marshall paces the Hopkins scorers with a total of 17
goals in eight games. Arlyn will be playing his final game as a Jay
tomorrow.

Terps Lead Series
Maryland, on the other hand,
wants to make their championship unanimous and finish its second undefeated season; extend its
18-17-1 series lead over Hopkins
and keep its 22 game win streak
intact.
Hopkins coach, Bob Scott commented, "We are in a good position since we will go into the
game as underdogs. We have
everything to gain and little to
lose. We feel no pressure, but I
am sure that the boys would like
to finish the season with a flourish
by topping Maryland. The boys
will have to give their top effort
to win this game, since they all
realize the strength of this Maryland team."
Last year the Terps downed the
Jays by a 11-5 count after being
held to a 5-5 tie after three quarters.
Jays Top Navy
Rallying to score six times In
the second half, the Hopkins lacrosse squad scored an 8-6 triumph over Navy at Annapolis before 3,000 fans last Saturday.
This victory extended the Jay
winning streak to six in a row, the
longest Hopkins win skein since
1950, and gave the Jays their first
victory over the Tars since 1951.
It also marked the third consecutive week that the Jays have
come from behind to capture a
triumph.
(Continued on Pape 8)

Hoping to gain their first
Homecoming Day victory since
1951 and to end the current collegiate campaign on a successful
note, the Blue Jay stickmen face
the 1956 National Lacrosse Champions, Maryland, tomorrow at
Homewood Field at 2:30 p.m.
Last Saturday the Jays as.sured
the Terps of their second straight
title by beating second, place Navy
by an 8-6 score at Annapolis.

Terps Undefeated

Maryland, on the other hand, has rolled over ten straight
opponents, compiling a total of 151 goals along the way, an
average of fifteen per game. The Terp lineup is dotted with
All-Americans and this group is led by Charlie Wicker who
has run up the fantastic total of 20 goals and 43 assists
this season. Jim Keating has added 24 goals to the Maryland cause.
However, it has been proven countless times that no
team, not even the mighty Maryland, is invincible. The Terps
can be beaten and Maryland has met no team this year more
capable of doing it than Hopkins.
Frosh Vs. Varsity

While we are on the subject of lacrosse we'd like to add
a word about the freshman team. In the early part of the
season, many Hopkins lacrosse fans were shifting their
allegiance to the frosh and leaving the varsity on its own.
While it is admirable for the frosh teams to have fan support, we don't think it should come at the expense of the
varsity. Wouldn't it look nice if the 20,000 fans per game
the Orioles average, suddenly made an excursion to San
Antonio to see the Missions play and left the Birds to play
to.an empty house. It has often been said that it is easy to
stick with a winner and this, it seems, was the reason for
early desertion of the varsity stickmen. However, let it be
said that the frosh are not all-conquering either, having
been beaten in two scrimmaged with Maryland Lacrosse
Club, even though M.L.C. was without several of its stars
on both occasions. Before anyone thinks this is a knock at
the freshman lacrosse team, it should be said that we think
Wilson Fewster has done a wonderful job with the frosh
and that several of the players will aid the varsity immeasurably in the future.
JAY JOTTINGS ... Hopkins track coach John Bridgers
has proven himself quite a prognosticator. Before last week's
Mason-Dixon track and field championships Bridgers said
that the chief threats to meet records would be Dave Foltz
of Roanoke, Charley Nuttycombe of Randolph-Macon, Jim
Frazier of Hampden-Sydney, and Taylor Goode of Lynchburg. Meet results show that all four came through with
record-shattering performances, Foltz breaking two marks.
• .. George Breslau, Jay attackman, was called "Indian"
by his teammates earlier in the season but after he led the
second half charge against R.P.I. Breslau was dubbed "Chief"
by trainer Jimmy Benson.... In Saturday's fracas between
the Jay frosh and the Navy Plebes the frosh managed to
get five men sent to the sidelines at the same time. However,
Navy could get only one goal while the skeleton crew was on
the field. ... Either the frosh or varsity squad, or both,
has run up a winning record in every spring sport save golf.
• • • Frosh baseballer Bill Corrigan also twirls for Leone's
Cafe sandlot nine, which is rated the top 16-18-year-old
team in Maryland.... Hopkins finished second in the recent
Mason-Dixon Conference golf tournament with a total score
Of. 698. Marc Leventhal and Lee Kolakowski led the way
With 36-hole scores of 170 and 172, respectively. Loyola
was the team winner for the seventh consecutive year....
Bob Scott feels that Rutgers has the second best lacrosse
team in the nation, behind Maryland. Hmm!... See you at
the game.

The goal of this exhibit is to
demonstrate that the art of photography is a dynamic process of
giving form to ideas and of explaining man to man. It was conceived by Steichen as "a mirror
of the universal elements and emotions in the everydayness of life—
as a mirror of the essential oneness of mankind throughout the
world." Subject matter ranges
from babies to philosophers, from
the kindergarten to the university,
from primitive peoples to the
Councils of the United Nations.
There is emphasis on the daily
relationships of man himself, to
his family, and to the community.
This is the original exhibition
which has been touring a limited
number of museums throughout

SC Reveals
Voting Delay
Of No Set Time
The Student Council referendum on its proposed constitution,
scheduled for last Wednesday and
Thursday, will be postponed indefinitely until some time in October as a result of action taken
at last Monday's SC meeting.
Penn Lupovitch, Constitution
Committee chairman, stated, "I
wish to apologize for the poor job
that has been done on this proposed referendum. If any blame
is to be laid, it must be here."
Added Lupovitch, "The Council
tried very hard to do this thing
correctly. The next time it will be
done correctly."
Lew Sank, president of the SC,
felt that "it would be more advantageous to the students to let
them express themselves by voting on the constitution" in explaining why he stepped down
from the chair to argue against
postponement. Said Sank, "The
SC made adequate attempts to
receive all discussions and suggestions. I felt that rather than
wait a year, the SC could obtain
overall opinion on the constitution by this referendum. The
majority of the SC felt that they
would rather be sure of student
support. To my mind the SC was
afraid of the present apathy which
exists in the dorm concerning
governing bodies and constitutions in general."
Lupovitch explained that the
action was taken after the meeting ran an hour and a half because the SC "general concensus
of opinion [was] that the student body had not been adequately
informed as to the intent and objects of the S.C. constitution. We,
as representatives of the student
body, feel that there has not been
enough time devoted to explanation and clarification on this proposed constitution," said Lupovitch.

Needed: The Human Touch

At the present time, the Alumni Memorial Residences
are not the most pleasant place in which to live. There is
very little, if any, feeling of belonging to a community
amongst those who reside in them.
This morning the Hopkins' film "The University" stated
through the words of John Masefield, one of the prime functions of a university. This is to "give the young people that
close companionship for which youth longs ... and that
chance of the endless discussion of the themes which are
endless ... without which youth would seem a waste of
time." Although this vital spirit of companionship is not
totally wanting in the dorms, it is effectively suppressed.
The residency is divided in an amazingly thorough manner. Fraternity men tend to be at least socially separated
from independents. Engineers are curricularly separated
from men in the school of Arts and Sciences. To a lesser
degree, the classes are separated, merely through associations. The house system, whereby the dormitories are divided
into separate entries was originally planned to promote
a strong unity of subdivisions. However, in its present
status, the system encourages the isolation of cliques rather
than the desired unity of medium sized groups.
By themselves, none of these separations are final
enough to cause the sense of disunity to be present. The
isolation factor is this: although there are several points
at which the interest and activities of the residents of the
dormitory differ, there is no encouragement for a union of
the various factors, nor is there any obvious advantage in
such a union. There is no common ground for an amalgamation.
The dormitory resident needs to feel that he belongs
to more than his immediate circle of friends if the previously stated goal of the university is to be fulfilled. He
needs a place, and above all, a reason to break his cliques.
At the present time there is no situation or location conducive to informal discussions between non-acquainted dormitory residents. The provision of a room for such purposes
would not be sufficient; indeed, there are ample facilities
available at present.
Perhaps a suggestion could be taken from "The University," which depicted a. member of the faculty mingling
with dormitory student in what is loosely termed a bull
session. If student-faculty discussions such as this actually
did take place in the dormitories, a step would be taken in
the provision of an opyortunity to discuss "the themes
which are endless." An arrangement in the order of the
'Y' Coffee Hours in the dormitories might suffice for a
beginning.
Another serious oversight in planning a well-rounded
dormitory life is the lack of an effective social program.
There is no provision for an informal mixing of the sees.
With the exception of the few, and only partially effective,
mixers, all acquaintances are made off campus. It would
not be impossible for the less aggressive 'resident of the
Alumni Memorial Residences to go throughout the academic
year without more than a passing acquaintance with the
opposite sex.
Since it is impossible for the four year student to have
a complete understanding of a situation which has built .up
over a period of years, without direct knowledge of what
the past held, or of what possibilities of improvement may
exist, we feel that it is not the part of the student to attempt to ameliorate the present oppressive atmosphere in
the dormitories. We must place our hope in an administrative understanding of the situation to guide the needed
changes.

Collegiate Tradition Expressed
In Riots, Raids, Boisterousness

s

NO RIOT HERE
Collegiate tradition points to
riots, raids, and boisterousness as
one of the signs that spring has
come to the collegiate community.
A quick scanning of the newspapers any weekend quickly bears
this out.
At Hopkins, tradition seems to
be hurting, for busy students, sunbathers, and "stickmen" aren't
very indicative of riotus universitatus. A number of reasons could
be advanced for this unusual behavior, not the least of which
would be that there has been unfavorable weather—either too hot,
too cold, or too rainy. Any student of collegiat spring riots is
fully aware that the hearty men
are not so dedicated to their principles of boisterousness to venture forth without proper weather.
So far this year, Dean Shaffer has
been blessed with adverse weather.
But. the University of Pennsylvania administration has not been
nearly so lucky.
It seems that a couple of weeks
ago, spring in all her glory came
to Philadelphia. It was one of
those days of which riot leaJcrs
dream, warm and balmy without
any activity. It was a Thursday.
This fracas, as do so many, started
quite innocently. Four men destined to achieve the goal of riot
leader, \--ere playing softball in
the street adjacent to the campus.
Playing ball with four People for
a couple of hours after supper
finally loses it,s enjoyment and this
game was no exception.
Nearby an ancient building was
rapidly coming to its inglorious
end at the hands of a wrecking
Company. To one of these budding
geniuses tiring of softball the idea
of placing debris from the building in the middle of the street
presented itself. This plan was
eagerly adopted by the other members of the quartet and they were
soon joined in the task by numerous undergraduate friends. This
was 9 P.M.
At 2 A.M., squads of weary
Policemen could finally return to
their stations. At 2 A.M., 116
Penn undergraduates were experiencing booking on the police
blotter. In the intervening five
hours buses, streetcars, autos, and
trucks had been blocked, eggs and
then stones had been hurled at
the policemen, some so accurately
that two officers had been injured, one requiring hospitaliza-

tion. On Friday in the solemn confines of Philadelphia Police Court
bengath the stern countenance of
magistrate John L. Carlyle, 28
were given a hearing and ordered
held on $500 bail on disorderly
conduct charges.
Apparently all is not over, for
Dr. Gayland P. Harnwell, president of the University of Pennsylvania, is quite disturbed over the
incident and has promised strong
disciplinary action.

NEWS-LETTER

PAGE SEVEN

Stickmen Continue Win Streak;
To Battle Maryland Tomorrow
By AL FIGINSKI
Assistant Sports Editor

By BOB MARTINI
Sports Editor

The Jay lacrosse squad, having won six games in a
row, face their toughest match of the season tomorrow
when they take on the highly touted Terrapins of Maryland
in the annual Homecoming game. Maryland, as expected,
has dominated the collegiate lacrosse scene this year, winning
10 straight contests and adding to their consecutive game
streak which has now reached 22 in a row. The streak,
ironically enough, began on Homecoming Day in 1954
When the Terps massacred Hopkins by a 17-4 score. From
this corner, this would be just as good a time as any to break
the Maryland bubble. Whether the Jaks have the club that
can do it or not remains the burning question. Hopkins this
year has had its best season since the 1950 championship
team. After dropping their first two tilts by one-goal margins, the Jays found themselves and, despite a severe lack
of fan support in their next four games, whipped all four
Opponents, including highly rated Army. After beating Army
the Jays returned home to face R.P.I. in a game which saw
one of the biggest crowds of the season turn out. The fans
were treated to a marvelous game, the Jays coming back
from a four goal deficit to whip Rensselaer, 10-7. Last week
Hopkins capped their six-game streak by upsetting Navy
by an 8-6 count.

Maryland, who will carry a 22
game winning streak into tomorrow's fray, are led by their two
co-captains, Gruder Miller, attackman, and Jack Simmons, defenseman. The visitors will also
bring with them their two leading
scorers, Jim Keating and Charlie
Wicker, who will pose a definite
threat to the Hopkins defense.
Terps Hold Edge
Statistically the Terps hold the
edge. In ten games the champs
have averaged 15.1 goals per game
offensively, while holding their op-

ponents to a mean of 4.6 goals.
The Jays possess an 8.5 average
offensively and hold a 5 goal average defensively.
Both teams have several reasons
for wanting to capture a victory
tomorrow. Hopkins hopes to extend their winning streak to seven
games; gain second place in the
final Cy Miller division and national rankings; end the long
Terp winning streak that was
started two years ago at the Jays'
expense and win their first Homecoming since 1951.

Arlyn Marshall, Jay Co-captain, brings the ball upfield in an
intra-squad game as the Jays prepare for tomorrow's clash with
Maryland. Marshall paces the Hopkins scorers with a total of 17
goals in eight games. Arlyn will be playing his final game as a Jay
tomorrow.

Terps Lead Series
Maryland, on the other hand,
wants to make their championship unanimous and finish its second undefeated season; extend its
18-17-1 series lead over Hopkins
and keep its 22 game win streak
intact.
Hopkins coach, Bob Scott commented, "We are in a good position since we will go into the
game as underdogs. We have
everything to gain and little to
lose. We feel no pressure, but I
am sure that the boys would like
to finish the season with a flourish
by topping Maryland. The boys
will have to give their top effort
to win this game, since they all
realize the strength of this Maryland team."
Last year the Terps downed the
Jays by a 11-5 count after being
held to a 5-5 tie after three quarters.
Jays Top Navy
Rallying to score six times In
the second half, the Hopkins lacrosse squad scored an 8-6 triumph over Navy at Annapolis before 3,000 fans last Saturday.
This victory extended the Jay
winning streak to six in a row, the
longest Hopkins win skein since
1950, and gave the Jays their first
victory over the Tars since 1951.
It also marked the third consecutive week that the Jays have
come from behind to capture a
triumph.
(Continued on Pape 8)

Hoping to gain their first
Homecoming Day victory since
1951 and to end the current collegiate campaign on a successful
note, the Blue Jay stickmen face
the 1956 National Lacrosse Champions, Maryland, tomorrow at
Homewood Field at 2:30 p.m.
Last Saturday the Jays as.sured
the Terps of their second straight
title by beating second, place Navy
by an 8-6 score at Annapolis.

Terps Undefeated

Maryland, on the other hand, has rolled over ten straight
opponents, compiling a total of 151 goals along the way, an
average of fifteen per game. The Terp lineup is dotted with
All-Americans and this group is led by Charlie Wicker who
has run up the fantastic total of 20 goals and 43 assists
this season. Jim Keating has added 24 goals to the Maryland cause.
However, it has been proven countless times that no
team, not even the mighty Maryland, is invincible. The Terps
can be beaten and Maryland has met no team this year more
capable of doing it than Hopkins.
Frosh Vs. Varsity

While we are on the subject of lacrosse we'd like to add
a word about the freshman team. In the early part of the
season, many Hopkins lacrosse fans were shifting their
allegiance to the frosh and leaving the varsity on its own.
While it is admirable for the frosh teams to have fan support, we don't think it should come at the expense of the
varsity. Wouldn't it look nice if the 20,000 fans per game
the Orioles average, suddenly made an excursion to San
Antonio to see the Missions play and left the Birds to play
to.an empty house. It has often been said that it is easy to
stick with a winner and this, it seems, was the reason for
early desertion of the varsity stickmen. However, let it be
said that the frosh are not all-conquering either, having
been beaten in two scrimmaged with Maryland Lacrosse
Club, even though M.L.C. was without several of its stars
on both occasions. Before anyone thinks this is a knock at
the freshman lacrosse team, it should be said that we think
Wilson Fewster has done a wonderful job with the frosh
and that several of the players will aid the varsity immeasurably in the future.
JAY JOTTINGS ... Hopkins track coach John Bridgers
has proven himself quite a prognosticator. Before last week's
Mason-Dixon track and field championships Bridgers said
that the chief threats to meet records would be Dave Foltz
of Roanoke, Charley Nuttycombe of Randolph-Macon, Jim
Frazier of Hampden-Sydney, and Taylor Goode of Lynchburg. Meet results show that all four came through with
record-shattering performances, Foltz breaking two marks.
• .. George Breslau, Jay attackman, was called "Indian"
by his teammates earlier in the season but after he led the
second half charge against R.P.I. Breslau was dubbed "Chief"
by trainer Jimmy Benson.... In Saturday's fracas between
the Jay frosh and the Navy Plebes the frosh managed to
get five men sent to the sidelines at the same time. However,
Navy could get only one goal while the skeleton crew was on
the field. ... Either the frosh or varsity squad, or both,
has run up a winning record in every spring sport save golf.
• • • Frosh baseballer Bill Corrigan also twirls for Leone's
Cafe sandlot nine, which is rated the top 16-18-year-old
team in Maryland.... Hopkins finished second in the recent
Mason-Dixon Conference golf tournament with a total score
Of. 698. Marc Leventhal and Lee Kolakowski led the way
With 36-hole scores of 170 and 172, respectively. Loyola
was the team winner for the seventh consecutive year....
Bob Scott feels that Rutgers has the second best lacrosse
team in the nation, behind Maryland. Hmm!... See you at
the game.

TER
SPORTS SECTION
Loyola Tops
Jay Batsmen
In Finale
Although the Blue Jay batsmen
outhit Loyola, the Evergreen nine
clustered its safeties to score twice
in the first, three times in the
sixth and twice in the seventh
innings and defeated the Jays by
a 7-3 score at Homewood Wednesday.
Three of the Hopkins eight hits
went for extra bases, while the
Greyhounds 'could manage only
two long hits in their total of six.
The Jays scored twice in the
fifth frame to take a brief 3-2
lead. The Hopkins tallies crossed
the plate as a result of successive
triples off the bats of Tony Salem,
Howie Alfandre, and John Newton.
Alfandre, Frank Hyde and Bill
Rock each collected two hits off
the Mason-Dixon Northern Division Champions.

Frosh Lacrossers Seek
Win Over Terps Today
Seeking their sixth consecutive
lacrosse victory of the campaign
and hoping to end the season with
an undefeated record, the Hopkins Frosh sticismen travel to College Park to engage the Terrapin
freshmen this afternoon in the
season finale for both clubs.
Maryland, holders of a 4-2 verdict over the Navy Plebes, are expected to give the Jays one of
their toughest battles of the campaign, according to Hopkins coach
Wilson Fewster.
Fledglings Drub Navy
Last Saturday the fledgling
Blue Jays traveled to Annapolis
and handed the Navy Plebes a
15-3 drubbing in a game marked
by penalties and the scoring of
Mickey Webster.
The Jays surged to a 6-1 lead

Dr. Jantz comes to Hopkins

groundwork for the exchange program had been laid by Professor
Arno Schirokauer shortly before
his death and that the program
would be continued in future
years.

The goal of this exhibit is to
demonstrate that the art of photography is a dynamic process of
giving form to ideas and of explaining man to man. It was conceived by Steichen as "a mirror
of the universal elements and emotions in the everydayness of life—
as a mirror of the essential oneness of mankind throughout the
world." Subject matter ranges
from babies to philosophers, from
the kindergarten to the university,
from primitive peoples to the
Councils of the United Nations.
There is emphasis on the daily
relationships of man himself, to
his family, and to the community.
This is the original exhibition
which has been touring a limited
number of museums throughout
the country.
